narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Had a great introduction to many different parts of Number Theory and the different ways to approach it through analysis / combinatorics / geometry, get to see a whole bunch of really cool theorems and in-depth proofs. Got much better at proof writing through the p-sets which are challenging but not unreasonable.

This course covered so many interesting topics in number theory. Professor Pohoata did a great job finding a balance between the number of topics and the depth we went into each one. I know I'll be thinking about some of the lectures long after the course is over.

I understood so much more about the structure of number theory. We saw all sorts of perspectives: analytic, algebraic, even geometric! Cosmin tied it all together in a beautiful way. We started off by learning some basic number theory: mods, orders, Chinese Remainder and the like. We very quickly moved on to fascinating topics such as generating functions, Unique Factorization, quadratic reciprocity, Sums of Squares, Geometry of Numbers, Combinatorial Nullstellensatz, and finite fields. Everything went just deep enough to show us a beautiful result or two and maybe a related open problem of research interest, but not deep enough to get lost. This was the most exhilarating view of number theory I've had.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course was its teaching. Professor Pohoata was so clear in his lectures, and was willing to go slower when we were confused. He did a great job finding a balance between the number of topics and the depth we went into each one. He was also just incredibly kind and understanding about the difficult circumstances of the semester.

This class was pretty much flawless for what it was meant to do. We spent just the right amount of time on every topic, and we were always ready to dive into the next one. I never felt lost. Topics were self-contained, but were also in constant dialogue. Results from one part of the course made surprise appearances elsewhere, such as the interplay between quadratic residues and finite fields, or the geometry of numbers and diophantine equations, or finite fields and nullstellensatz, or... it goes on
if i had to give criticism, I think we could have maybe had a little bit more homework.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Pohoata was incredibly kind and understanding about the difficult circumstances of the semester. I appreciated that the lectures were recorded, and that he labelled which topics were covered in each video - it made it way easier to go back and rewatch the right lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This course is amazing, especially with Cosmin. Lectures are spent proving really cool theorems in-depth, and a wide variety of approaches to the subject are covered: we even spent some classes proving a single theorem (quadratic reciprocity) through a bunch of different methods. You'll get to see lots of approaches to number theory and it's super fun!

This course covered so many interesting topics in number theory. Professor Pohoata did a great job finding a balance between the number of topics and the depth we went into each one. I know I'll be thinking about some of the lectures long after the course is over.

Yes! This is mostly geared towards math majors: there's that Gauss quote about number theory being the queen of mathematics, which I find mostly true. There is a sense of amazement in how all these things are pieced together. It's also a very good review for many notions seen in 350 and 370. It's also relatively low-workload, though there are lots of concepts to study if you want to get maximal value out of this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
